Consequence Analysis Guidance.  The following paragraphs provide details of the chosen scenarios.

The worst case release scenario submitted for Program 2 and 3 toxic substances as a class involves a catastrophic release from the South Casting Department Chlorine Storage and Delivery System.  The scenario involves the release of 8000 pounds of Chlorine in a gaseous form over 10 minutes.  Passive mitigation controls such as enclosures are also taken into account to calculate the scenario.  At Class F atmospheric stability and 1.5 meters per second (m/s) wind speed, the maximum distance of 9.9 miles is obtained corresponding to a toxic endpoint of 0.0087 milligrams per liter (mg/l).

One alternative release scenario has been submitted for each toxic substance present in Program 2 and Program 3 processes cumulatively.

The alternative release scenario for Chlorine involves a release from the Chlorine Storage and Delivery System of the South Cast House.  The scenario involves the release of 450.00 pounds of Chlorine in a gaseous form over a period of thirty minutes.  Passive  mitigation controls such as enclosures are taken into account to calculate the scenario.  In addition, the release is assumed to be controlled by an active mitigation measure, which include sprinkler system(s).  Under neutral weather conditions, the maximum distance to the toxic endpoint of 0.0087 mg/L of Chlorine is 0.38 miles.

4. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific  
Prevention Steps

Commonwealth Aluminum Lewisport, LLC. has taken the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set forth in 40 CFR part 68.  The facility is also subject to the notification  requirements of the Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act under Section 302.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at our stationary source.

Process Safety Information
Commonwealth Aluminu

m Lewisport, LLC. maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.

Process Hazard Analysis
Commonwealth Aluminum Lewisport, LLC. conducts studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  Current process quantities are below the Process Safety Management requirements.  The methodology used to carry out these analyses include what-if, check-lists, and a combination thereof.  The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at a regular interval of three years.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.


Operating Procedures
For the purposes of safely conducting activities within our covered processes, Commonwealth Aluminum Lewisport, LLC. maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup after an outage.  The information is regularly reveiwed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the process.

Training
Commonwealth Aluminum Lewisport, LLC. has a training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures asssociated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided at least every two years and more frequently as needed.

Mechanical Integrity
Commonwealth Aluminum Lewisport, LLC. carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others; pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previ

ddition, employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular.

Contractors
Contractors, who conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities at the facility, are required to undergo a thorough evaluation of safety performance guidelines as stipulated in the General Contractor Safety Program. Commonwealth Aluminum Lewisport, LLC. has a policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes.  Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.

5. Five-year Accident History

Commonwealth Aluminum Lewisport, LLC. has an record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years.  Due to release prevention policies, there has been no reportable release during this period.

6. Emergency Response Plan

Commonwealth Aluminum Lewisport, LLC. maintains a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies an the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.

To ensure proper functioning, our emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within any processes that would require a modified emergency response.

7. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Safety audits and employee interactions are continually observed at Commonwealth Aluminum Lewisport, LLC. to provide the safest available working environment achievable.  Based upon the previous upgrades to the pertinent Chlorine Storage and Delivery System (i.e., construction of remote enclosure with automated atmospheric mon

itoring technologies installed in and around the perimeter), there are currently no safety improvements deemed necessary during the time that this executive summary is prepared.

RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM
GENERAL EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Commonwealth Aluminum Lewisport, LLC.,is committed to employee, public, and environmental safety.  This commitment is illustrated through the implemetation of a accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility.  Commonwealth Aluminum Lewisport, LLC. is continually establishing and revising policies to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances into the surrounding communities and natural environments.  Trained emergency response personnel are at hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release.

2. The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled

Commonwealth Aluminum Lewisport, LLC. is classified as a secondary aluminum processor whose primary activities encompass the melting and refining of scrap aluminum to produce aluminum ingot via direct chill methods; rolling ingots into aluminum rolls/products, and; performing coil coating processes on aluminum rolls.  This facility has one (1) regulated substance, chlorine, present above the specified threshold quantities as stipulated in 40 CFR 68.  This regulated substance is utilized in the degassing and refining processes of molten aluminum in the Casting Departments.

The maximum inventory of Chlorine (ten - 750 pound cylinders - 7500 pounds) that can be effected at Commonwealth Aluminum Lewisport, LLC. resides in a remote location found in the South Casting Department.

Management of Change
Written procedures are in place at Commonwealth Aluminum Lewisport, LLC. to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification.

Pre-startup Reviews
Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at Commonwealth Aluminum Lewisport, LLC.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits
Commonwealth Aluminum Lewisport, LLC. conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented.  These audits are carried out at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.

Incident Investigation
Commonwealth Aluminum Lewisport, LLC. promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring.  All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.
